title: @Riot, What's the lore/champion creation process?
body:
This is an out of the blue question for me, but since I've always had a nagging interest in video game development (never jumped on it...bills to pay, classes to study, etc), I'd like to know from you guys, how does it work? How long does it normally take you guys at each part of the process, or overall?

It would be great to have an example from an older champion/lore development that you guys have, but any information would be great.


Bonus question: What's the process for making skins for champions? How do you get your ideas?

replies.body:
I can help with this, though full disclosure: I'm currently doing work on the NA team, so this process likely has changed.

An example of lore I can give are the faction breakdowns - we'd start by setting a meeting for, say, Noxus. Then the team would get together in one of the more spacious conference rooms (it had a bean bag chair at one point) and break down what the current state of the faction's lore was. Main players? Important figures? Politics? History? Society? Future? We'd go through what existed, read some of the adjoining champion information, then begin a multi-week long series of meetings brainstorming what defined the places and people that make Noxus, well... Noxus.

On top of that, there were per-week short story submissions for everyone on the team, and those would go through rounds of critique to flesh out the most vibrant and cohesive vision of Noxian society/champs. During this period we'd also double up by having Noxus champion breakdowns, so we'd be simultaneously looking at, say, Katarina, while also looking at how and where she was raised and why. She would *also* have short story submissions during that time, which tended to include Cass, Talon, and her parents. After a while we'd feel comfortable *enough* to move on to another faction, so that we could cycle through them all until we ended up at Noxus for another round of iteration.

It was super fun, but also a TON of work. I have mad respect for those guys. In any event, hope that helps!

Many thanks for your input.
Although I'm unsure if you can help with this question: Say you're working a new champ for Noxus. How would that play into the whole series of lore exploration for the faction?

Champ teams are multidisciplinary, so a lot of the time everyone has a good feel for the current lore and how a new figure factors in. Much of the time it's very natural, some of the time we inadvertently expand on an existing champ while developing the new champ. Sometimes it's spontaneous. Sometimes we don't even know where the new champ fits in at all, so there are iterations ranging from a yordle to a cat dude to a space robot to a darkin and back before anyone agrees on where it should be placed. Of the two I've worked on, only one saw me inputting for story, and that process was really cool because any little thing could dramatically change both the character and the faction they came from, if not the entire dynamic of Runeterra.

Like I said, super fun!

Thanks again for your input. It sounds awesome.

Okay, time for bonus question: How would something like a champion skin get planned out? Is it as wild as a new champion?
Honestly? No idea. I assume they go with the manatee-in-a-tank-full-of-word-balls approach (which is awesome).

That's okay. Maybe someone else can pick this up.

Many thanks for your replies. You have made my day on these forums.

Thanks for the kind words! 

My personal process varies as one of my favorite methods of story research is to look to writers I admire and try to mimic their process.  A lot of times it involves researching various historical events (or trivial pop-culture tidbits) that I find interesting and then staring at a blank page for hours, scratching my head. Sometimes I write a sentence or two before invariably deleting it and rewriting. I believe this is called procrastination? Usually I rack up eight or nine beginnings before I take a plunge and write straight through to the end. 

A teacher had me do this really cool exercise once, where she told me to make a list of the stories/games/characters that I loved the most, then try to find the common threads that bound them together. Then it kind of synthesized into a personal creative statement that I go back to whenever I'm lost in a story or world and see how it impacts whatever I'm working on. 

I make a lot of playlists. LOADS of playlists. Probably why my iTunes doesn't load properly anymore. Anytime I need to slip into the mood of a story, it helps to have music ready to teleport me into the headspace I need to get into to write a character or a world.

I do something similar to this as well :P

I take a lot of inspiration from mythology in particular, especially greek/roman/norse. When I make a character (I do champ concepts on the side, and write short stories/novels-which-eventually-become-short-stories) I tend to focus on broad spectrum "what am I going for?" , then strengths, weaknesses, "what makes them tick", and so on. Though unless I get a good flow going, I'll only end up writing a few lines which will most likely get scrapped, or the concept/story gets scrapped, or cut off into a short story. I tend to lean towards radio/Pandora more, although the intermissions and commercials mess up my thought process sometimes.

Hiya! 

FauxSchizzle told me you had questions about how champion skins were created! I'm QA on the skins team, and can shed a bit of light on this subject.

There's several factors that determine which champion will get a skin and why. If we come up with an awesome skin idea for say Sivir, but it's winter-themed, we'll hold that idea for the Snowdown event. Same rules apply for other events, such as Lunar Revel or Harrowing. We also look at when a champion last had a skin, if we have a solid thematic for a new skin for x champion, how many skins x champion has, etc. 

The process itself involves severeal stages of ideation. 

Let's use Akali as an example, since Headhunter Akali just came out today and this is a skin I've worked on! 

We'll start by bringing everyone together to pitch ideas for Akali. Anything goes at this point! We'll also bring up player concepts that we've saved for Akali, and discuss those, too! Once we've got all the ideas written down, we vote on the ideas that we feel are the strongest.

From there, we concept what these ideas might look like. We'll then narrow it down a bit more and choose the strongest concept. This concept is then refined until we feel it's reached it's final form, and from there, begin creating the skin (models, textures, animations and particles.)

We review the progress of the skin, and give feedback accordingly throughout the process. During this time, bugs are fixed, and we make sure the skin is bug free (and looks pretty... or badass, accordingly!)

Once we've got the skin nearly finalized, we toss it out to the PBE for player feedback! QA Analysts like myself then gather the actionable feedback and deliver it back to the team for discussion. We'll make changes where we see fit based on said feedback, and those changes will appear on the PBE in the same cycle. Player feedback, both positive and negative, are super beneficial for us! For example, Blood Moon Elise had her outfit color changed three times based on feedback! Firecracker Jinx also gained a jade dragon tattoo! 

Once the PBE cycle is complete, we package it up and ship it to live!

Many thanks KateyKhaos! You filled out the last of three questions I had for you guys! Much respect to you guys for getting them answered!


I am curious of one thing, however: I feel that some champ skins get released willy-nilly. While I understand certain skins such as Snowdown (winter-themed), or Firecraker Jinx (Chinese New Year), other champs, like Dunkmaster Darius for example, seem a bit...thrown out there. Cool skin and everything, but unrelated to any holidays/Lore events (there's others I believe that fit this list, but I hope you understand what I'm trying to say).

So, are most skins released based on proper timing (holiday, Lore event, etc), or is it based more on a schedule (something like: "Hey, it's been a few months since we released a skin. Let's drop a new one.")?

There's definitely some skins that aren't tied to any events! 

We ideate several months in advance for a skin, and it's usually timed to be spaced apart from the previous skin for the champion. Again, there's exceptions for this if we have an awesome skin idea that fits well with an event. A good example of this would be Reaper Soraka and Order of the Banana Soraka. 

Even if it's not tied to an event, if it's a solid thematic, we're willing to ideate on it, and potentially ship it!

One question where along the lines do you usually decide whether or not to have it be 1350, 975 or 750, since I guess a legnedary and ultimate skin gets decided early on in the concept but what about the skin tiers that are less different

We try to define scope (what kinds of bells and whistles will be going into a skin) early on, usually while we're concepting the skin, so we have an idea of the resources we'll need. For example, if it's a 750 RP skin, we'll need someone to create a new model and texture, whereas for 975 RP+, we'll need a particle artist, an animator, and an audio dude!
